description: Length of longest run of consecutive quadratic residues mod prime(n).
comments: 0 and 1 are consecutive quadratic residues for any prime, so a(n) >= 2."Consecutive" allows wrap-around, so p-1 and 0 are consecutive. - _Robert Israel_, Jul 20 2014A002307(n) is defined similarly, except that only positive reduced quadratic residues are counted. - _Jonathan Sondow_, Jul 20 2014For longest runs of quadratic nonresidues, see A002308. - _Jonathan Sondow_, Jul 20 2014
links: Robert Israel, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
P. Pollack and E. Treviño, The primes that Euclid forgot, Amer. Math. Monthly, 121 (2014), 433-437.
formula: a(n) < 2*sqrt(prime(n)) for n >= 1 (see Pollack and Treviño for n > 1). - _Jonathan Sondow_, Jul 20 2014a(n) >= A002307(n). - _Jonathan Sondow_, Jul 20 2014
example: For n = 7, prime(7) = 17 has consecutive quadratic residues 15,16,0,1,2, and no longer sequence of consecutive quadratic residues, so a(7)=5.
maple: A:= proc(n) local P, res, nonres, nnr;     P:= ithprime(n);     res:= {seq(i^2,i=0..floor((P-1)/2)};     nonres:= {$1..P-1} minus res;     nnr:= nops(nonres);     max(seq(nonres[i+1]-nonres[i]-1,i=1..nnr-1),nonres[1]-nonres[-1]+P-1)end proc;A(1):= 2:seq(A(n),n=1..100); # _Robert Israel_, Jul 20 2014
author: _David W. Wilson_
extensions: Offset corrected to 1, definition clarified, _Jonathan Sondow_ Jul 20 2014
